Question: Does the video accurately depict President Trump visiting Maui after the August 2023 wildfires, or is it misleading?

Prediction.reasoning: To verify whether President Trump actually visited Maui after the August 2023 wildfires, an online search is necessary to access credible news sources and current events.

Query1.query: Did Donald Trump visit Maui after August 2023 wildfires? (site:cnn.com OR site:bbc.com OR site:nytimes.com)

Query2.query: Trump Maui wildfires response August 2023 news (site:axios.com OR site:wapo.com OR site:usatoday.com)

Query1.title: Biden says he plans to visit Maui soon as he mourns devastation ...
Query1.snippet: Aug 16, 2023 ... President Joe Biden on Tuesday said he will travel to Maui soon to visit the devastation left behind by wildfires that ravaged the Hawaiian¬†...

content.content:
President Joe Biden on Tuesday said he will travel to Maui soon to visit the devastation left behind by wildfires that ravaged the Hawaiian island last week, leaving scores dead and untold damage.
    

            In his first comments on the disaster since late last week, Biden said he wanted to ensure a possible presidential visit wouldn‚Äôt impede recovery efforts.
    

            ‚ÄúMy wife Jill and I are going to travel to Hawaii as soon as we can, that‚Äôs what I‚Äôve been talking to governor about,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to get in the way ‚Äì I‚Äôve been to too many disaster areas, but I want to go and make sure we got everything they need. I want to be sure we don‚Äôt disrupt the ongoing recovery efforts.‚Äù
    

            The remarks were Biden‚Äôs first public comments about the unfolding disaster in Hawaii since last Thursday, when he similarly began a prescheduled speech addressing the devastation. The period of silence had not gone unnoticed by Biden‚Äôs critics, including former President Donald Trump and other Republicans.
    

            Biden‚Äôs aides have pointed to the president‚Äôs frequent phone calls with FEMA leadership, Hawaii‚Äôs congressional delegation and its governor as evidence of his sustained engagement. So far, Democrats have publicly supported Biden‚Äôs response. The president has been in regular contact with Hawaii Gov. Josh Green, who has publicly praised the administration‚Äôs response and the president‚Äôs ‚Äúfull support.‚Äù Sen. Mazie Hirono of Hawaii...[Content truncated]

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses President Biden's plans to visit Maui following the wildfires, which reveals that no visit from Trump occurred around that time. Since it indicates Biden's presence instead of Trump in the aftermath of the wildfires, it indirectly supports the conclusion that the video claiming Trump visited Maui is likely misleading.

So far, family members of missing people have provided 41 DNA samples, trying to see whether their loved ones are among the dead, county officials said. Query1.title: Bidens to visit Hawaii on Monday following Maui wildfires | CNN ...
Query1.snippet: Aug 16, 2023 ... The relative silence did not go unnoticed by Biden's critics, including former President Donald Trump and other Republicans, and the Biden¬†...

content.content:
President Joe Biden and first lady Dr. Jill Biden will travel to Hawaii on Monday, the White House announced, as search, rescue and recovery efforts continue following the devastating wildfires there.
    

            ‚ÄúThe President and First Lady will travel to Maui on Monday, August 21 to meet with first responders, survivors, as well as federal, state, and local officials, in the wake of deadly wildfires on the island,‚Äù White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said in a statement.
    

            The planned visit comes amid mounting pressure on Biden, who ‚Äì despite signing a federal disaster declaration last week ‚Äì had only sparingly referenced the disaster, which has left at least 100 dead. The relative silence did not go unnoticed by Biden‚Äôs critics, including former President Donald Trump and other Republicans, and the Biden administration in recent days has been promoting its commitment to helping local authorities recover and rebuild.
    

            The Bidens, Jean-Pierre said, will ‚Äúsee firsthand the impacts of the wildfires and the devastating loss of life and land that has occurred on the island, as well as discuss the next steps in the recovery effort.‚Äù
    

            Biden said in Wisconsin on Tuesday that he did not want a presidential visit, which requires a significant security and operational footprint, to interfere with efforts or divert response resources on the ground. 
    

            But Hawaii Democratic Gov. Josh Green, Jean-Pierre said, ‚Äúadvised that the search and recovery efforts are expected to be at a stage early next week to allow for a presidential visit.‚Äù
    

            The White House is taking care to ensure Biden‚Äôs visit to Hawaii will not disrupt recovery efforts on the island, FEMA Administrator Deanne Criswell told reporters Wednesday.
    

            ‚ÄúOur biggest goal was to make sure that we weren‚Äôt going to disrupt the ability of our search and rescue teams to continue their operations, and when I was just briefing the president and he spoke with [Green], he asked the governor if this was going to be an appropriate time and the governor agreed,‚Äù Criswell told reporters during Wednesday‚Äôs White House press briefing.
    

            Biden has stayed in close...[Content truncated]

Query2.title: Video falsely claims Trump visited Maui amid wildfires| Fact check
Query2.snippet: Aug 18, 2023 ... Trump has not visited the Hawaiian island of Maui following the devastating wildfires there that killed more than 100 in early August.

content.content:
[Content truncated]... shows Trump visiting Maui after wildfires
----------------------------------------------------------
An Aug. 16 Facebook video (, ) shows a TikTok video that features former President Donald Trump and former first lady Melania Trump walking past a FEMA truck in a disaster-struck area and talking with people in a building filled with supplies and clothes.
‚ÄúTHE PEOPLE'S PRESIDENT,‚Äù reads text on the screen. ‚ÄúThank you Mr. Trump for checking on the people of Maui!‚Äù
The Facebook video was shared over 900 times in one day, while the original TikTok video has been shared more than 7,000 times.
**Follow us on Facebook!** 
Our rating: False
-----------------
The video is years old and shows the former president's 2019 visit to Alabama after a tornado damaged part of the state. Trump has not visited the Hawaiian island of Maui following the devastating wildfires there that killed more than 100 in early August.
Video shows Trump visiting Alabama in 2019
------------------------------------------
At least¬†¬†have died in wildfires that consumed parts of Maui, the second-largest of the Hawaiian islands, since¬†.¬†But there is no evidence the former president has visited the island.
The video shared on Facebook shows then-president Trump delivering remarks to a group of people at Providence Baptist Church in Opelika, Alabama, on March 8, 2019, after the area was struck by a tornado that caused serious damage and left  injured. The church was serving as a disaster relief center for those affected.
The White House shared footage of the visit on  the same day. His full comments can be found in the White House‚Äôs .
**Fact check**: 
There are no credible reports that Trump has gone to visit Maui amid the island‚Äôs wildfires. However, the former president did  about the crisis.
USA TODAY reached out to the user who shared the post for comment but did not immediately receive a response.
Our fact-check sources:
-----------------------
*   WFSA 12 News, March 3, 2022, 
*   Trump White House, March 8, 2019,  (YouTube)
*   Trump White House, March 8, 2019, 
*   Trump Campaign, Aug. 14,

This provides direct confirmation that the original claim is false, making it highly relevant.

Entire city forced to evacuate as Canada's wildfires get worse
--------------------------------------------------------------
"Unprecedented" wildfires closing in on the capital of Canada's Northwest Territories prompted citywide evacuations by land and sky Thursday, officials said. Authorities instructed residents of the highest-risk areas of Yellowknife to evacuate immediately, while others had until Friday afternoon to leave the city of about 20,000 people.¬†Canada has been plagued by the worst wildfire season on record.¬†The effects will be felt in the U.S., too: An air quality alert was issued across the entire state of Wisconsin, and central and northeastern Minnesota, from Thursday morning through Monday. **__**

Query2.title: Maui police release report on Lahaina fire response
Query2.snippet: Feb 5, 2024 ... ... August and razed the historic town of Lahaina. The big picture: The Lahaina fire killed at least 100 people, and Maui Police Chief John¬†...

content.content:
Read: Maui police release report on response to deadly wildfires
----------------------------------------------------------------
!
*   
!
An aerial view of burned structures in Lahaina, Hawai'i, in October ‚Äî two months after a devastating wildfire swept the island of Maui. Photo: Mario Tama/Getty Images
The  Police Department released a preliminary report Monday on authorities' response to the devastating  last August and razed the historic town of Lahaina.
**The big picture:** The Lahaina fire killed at least  people, and Maui Police Chief John Pelletier noted at  announcing the "after-action"  that "the search is not over" for three people still listed as missing from the island's blaze that destroyed thousands of acres and structures.
*   The cause of the fire on Maui is still being investigated and this preliminary report analyzes the police's response to the tragedy and makes 32 recommendations for improvements to better prepare for any future catastrophe, as well as identifying what worked well.
**What they found:** The report finds that the Maui PD was understaffed as officers in the Lahaina District faced communications and equipment issues as they responded to "critical events" at the same time in multiple different locations issues, such as downed trees
*   "At most times, this radio traffic was being monitored by and responded to by a single dispatcher. ... on a typical day, radio channels will have at most 15 officers working over a single radio frequency," notes the report.
*   Officers responded to multiple safety hazard reports, including "downed trees, utility poles, power lines, debris on roads, power outages, non-functional traffic signals, and compromised cellular and internet services."
*   Fallen poles and debris blocked roads, leaving traffic gridlocked as the Lahaina fire spread, prompting a large-scale evacuation of "over a thousand people" at one center, many of whom. the report noted, were without vehicles.
*   Several disinformation campaigns were identified as the tragedy unfolded...[Content truncated]

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence focuses on the response of Maui police to the wildfires and does not mention Trump or confirm or deny his visit to Maui. Thus, it is largely irrelevant to the specific claim.

QA.Question: Does the video accurately depict President Trump visiting Maui after the August 2023 wildfires, or is it misleading?
QA.Answer: The video in question is misleading in its claim that President Donald Trump visited Maui after the August 2023 wildfires. The evidence indicates that Trump has not visited the Hawaiian island in the aftermath of the disaster. Instead, the video that's being circulated actually shows a past event, specifically a visit Trump made in March 2019 to Alabama following a tornado. This misunderstanding has led to the video being falsely portrayed as a recent visit to Maui, where he supposedly interacted with hurricane victims and volunteers. Moreover, during the time that the wildfires were devastating Maui, President Joe Biden was publicly discussing his planned visit to the island to assess the situation, which would have been inconsistent with Trump's involvement in the disaster response. This further supports the conclusion that the video is fabricated or manipulated, as there are no credible reports of Trump's presence in Maui during this time. In conclusion, the claim that the video accurately depicts President Trump visiting Maui post-wildfires is false; it misrepresents a past event and deceives viewers about his involvement in the response to the recent disaster.
